column6: Defined benefit plan obligations and other retirement plans
column7: Provisions for employee entitlements to annual leave, extended service leave and employee incentives (where the Group does not have an unconditional right to defer payment for at least twelve months after the reporting date) are recognised within the current provision for employee benefits and represent the amount which the Group has a present obligation to pay, resulting from employeesÃ¢ÂÂ services up to the reporting date. All other short-term employee benefit obligations are presented as payables. Liabilities for extended service leave where the Group has an unconditional right to defer payment for at least twelve months after the reporting date is recognised within the non-current provision for employee benefits.

TRIFR remains a key performance metric and is a measure within the Safety Index. We continue to aim for a year-on-year improvement in TRIFR, and in FY23, our TRIFR of 14.8 was a 9.2% improvement on FY22. It was delivered through a continued focus on risks, including manual handling, fleet safety and mental wellbeing. \t
Coles Group Limited is a publicly listed company. Group headquarters are at 800-838 Toorak Road, Hawthorn East, Victoria, 3123. The Group operates across Australia.

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Our 2023 Sustainability Report contains information for all Coles' wholly owned businesses during FY23 (unless otherwise stated).

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: The annual reporting frequency and the FY23 report were published on 14 September 2023. Contact point details are available on the inside cover of the 2023 Sustainability Report.
In FY23, we recalculated our target baseline data for Scope 1, 2 and 3 to account for the sale of Coles Express.\n

Ernst & Young (EY) was engaged by Coles Group Limited (Coles) to undertake limited assurance as defined by Australian Auditing Standards, hereafter referred to as a 'review', over specific sustainability data and disclosures in Coles' sustainability report and Data Pack for the year ended 25 June 2023.

The Board has established three standing committees and has delegated to each committee several duties to assist the Board in exercising its responsibilities and discharging its duties. Together, they play an essential role in helping the BoardÃ¢ÂÂs oversight and governance of the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs operations. Each committee has a separate charter that sets out the parts and responsibilities of that committee and the membership and other requirements for the committee process.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Leah Weckert is the Managing Director and Chief Executive Officer.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The role of the Board is to provide leadership and approve the strategic direction of the Group in the long-term interests of, and to maximise value to, shareholders, guide and monitor the management of the Group in achieving its strategic plans and desired culture by the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs core values, review, approve and monitor the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs risk management systems across its businesses, and to oversee overall good governance practice.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column7: The Board and management team are committed to maintaining and building on the confidence of our shareholders, customers, suppliers, team members and the broader community as we strive to achieve our vision to become the most trusted retailer in Australia and to grow long-term shareholder value.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column7: The Board oversees and approves the strategic direction of the Group and oversees the effectiveness of ColesÃ¢ÂÂ sustainability and governance policies and practices, including exposure to climate change and other environmental and social risks and opportunities. The Audit and Risk Committee supports the Board in fulfilling its responsibilities, including evaluating the adequacy and effectiveness of the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs identification and management of environmental and social sustainability risks and disclosing any material exposures to those risks, including financial and non-financial risks.

The Company aims to communicate all necessary information relating to Coles to its shareholders and implements processes to facilitate effective two-way communication with shareholders and other stakeholders. The Company recognises that potential investors and other interested stakeholders may wish to obtain information about Coles from time to time.

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column7: Knowledge is advanced through detailed updates provided to the Board and the Board Audit and Risk Committee related to Coles' sustainability strategy.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column7: An external Board effectiveness review was conducted during FY23 to assess the performance of the Board as a whole and its committees. The process was undertaken with the assistance of an external service provider and included a detailed questionnaire completed by Directors and senior management.

The Board maintains overall accountability for oversight of the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs remuneration policies to ensure they are aligned with the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs vision, values, strategic objectives and risk appetite. The Board approves all remuneration and benefit arrangements related to the Managing Director and CEO and executive-level direct reports to the Managing Director and CEO (Ã¢ÂÂExecutive Direct ReportsÃ¢ÂÂ) and the Non-executive Directors regarding the recommendations made by the People and Culture Committee. The Board maintains absolute discretion to either positively or negatively adjust the remuneration outcomes for the Managing Director and CEO and Executive Direct Reports. The Board will use its discretion based on the provision of supporting data and its assessment of performance aligned to the GroupÃ¢ÂÂs values and LEaD behaviours, risk, compliance, reputational, safety and sustainability considerations, and the quality of earnings delivered.

We know that now more than ever, our customers want to understand the sustainability of the products they purchase and the responsibility with which they are sourced. Waste management, including plastics, packaging and food, and ensuring animal welfare remains paramount. Additionally, we are committed to reducing emissions, which we know is also of increasing importance to our investors and other stakeholders.
